hurt.title: Create a Comfortable Resting Area
hurt.text: Ensure your dog has a quiet, cozy spot to rest, away from busy areas to help them relax.

hurt.title: Consider Pain Management Options
hurt.text: Consult with your vet about pain relief options, including medications, supplements, or alternative therapies.

hurt.title: Gentle Handling
hurt.text: Be mindful when touching or moving your dog, especially in areas that seem to cause discomfort.

hurt.title: Warm Compresses
hurt.text: For certain types of discomfort, warm compresses can soothe pain. Ask your vet if this is suitable for your dog’s condition.

hurt.title: Limit Strenuous Activity
hurt.text: Keep activities low-key to prevent exacerbating pain, focusing on gentle, brief interactions.

hunger.title: Warm the Food Slightly or Add Chicken Broth
hunger.text: Heating food can enhance its aroma, making it more appealing to your dog. A splash of chicken broth can also increase interest in food without overwhelming their senses.

hunger.title: Explore Meal Frequency
hunger.text: Discover what suits your dog best: one meal a day or smaller, more frequent meals. Tailoring feeding times can boost their appetite and well-being.

hunger.title: Experiment with Different Foods
hunger.text: Discovering your dog's preferences can be key. Try various healthy options, including wet food, dry food, or a mix to see what they prefer.

hunger.title: Ensure a Quiet, Comfortable Eating Space
hunger.text: A calm environment free from loud noises and high traffic can help your dog relax and focus on eating.

hunger.title: Keep Fresh Water Available
hunger.text: Hydration plays a crucial role in appetite. Offering fresh water alongside wet food options can help maintain hydration and encourage eating.

hunger.title: Use a Flat Dish for Easier Food Access
hunger.text: Some dogs find bowls intimidating or uncomfortable to eat from. A flat dish can make food more accessible and inviting.

hunger.title: Offer Food in Small Amounts at Regular Intervals
hunger.text: Consistent, small portions can help manage your dog's intake without overwhelming them, making meals more manageable.

hunger.title: Ensure Easy Access to Fresh Water at All Times
hunger.text: Dehydration can affect appetite. Making sure your dog has constant access to water is essential for their overall health and can improve eating habits.

hydration.title: Fresh Water Availability
hydration.text: Always have fresh, clean water available and encourage drinking by placing water bowls in several accessible locations.

hydration.title: Flavor the Water
hydration.text: Add a little flavor to the water, such as a small amount of chicken broth or tuna juice, to encourage drinking (consult your vet for safe options).

hydration.title: Wet Food Integration
hydration.text: Increase moisture intake by incorporating wet food into your dog’s diet, which can help with hydration.

hydration.title: Ice Cubes as Treats
hydration.text: Offer ice cubes as a low-calorie treat – some dogs enjoy licking or chewing on them.

hydration.title: Monitor for Dehydration
hydration.text: Learn the signs of dehydration (such as dry gums and lethargy) and consult your vet if you notice these symptoms.

hygiene.title: Regular Grooming Sessions
hygiene.text: Keep up with regular grooming to help your dog stay clean. This includes brushing, baths, and cleaning any soiled areas.

hygiene.title: Pet-Friendly Wipes
hygiene.text: Use pet-safe wipes for quick clean-ups, especially if your dog struggles with maintaining their cleanliness.

hygiene.title: Dental Care
hygiene.text: Maintain oral hygiene with appropriate dog toothbrushes and toothpaste to prevent dental diseases and keep them feeling fresh.

hygiene.title: Assist with Bathroom Needs
hygiene.text: For dogs that can’t clean themselves after going to the bathroom, gently clean them to prevent discomfort or infections.

hygiene.title: Comfortable Bedding
hygiene.text: Ensure bedding is clean and dry; change it regularly to prevent your dog from lying in dirt or moisture, which can lead to skin issues.

happiness.title: Identify Joy Triggers
happiness.text: Pay attention to activities or toys that previously brought joy to your dog. Even small interactions can uplift their mood.

happiness.title: Quality Time Together
happiness.text: Spend more time with your dog, offering gentle affection and companionship to boost their spirits.

happiness.title: New Experiences
happiness.text: Introduce new, low-stress activities or environments to stimulate their interest and engagement. Sometimes, a change of scenery can help.

happiness.title: Socialization
happiness.text: If your dog enjoys the company of other animals, consider play dates with familiar dogs to encourage positive social interactions.

happiness.title: Comfort Items
happiness.text: Provide your dog with comfort items, such as a favorite blanket or toy, to offer a sense of security and happiness.

happiness.title: Music Therapy
happiness.text: Some dogs find calm and comfort in soft music. Playing gentle tunes can create a soothing environment for your dog.

happiness.title: Consult a Vet
happiness.text: Persistent low happiness can be a sign of underlying health issues. A vet can provide advice on addressing potential medical causes.

mobility.title: Start with Short, Gentle Walks
mobility.text: Brief, leisurely walks can help maintain muscle tone and joint flexibility without putting too much strain on your dog.

mobility.title: Use Orthopedic Bedding for Extra Comfort
mobility.text: Orthopedic beds, like a memory-foam mattress, support joints and can prevent pain after resting, making movement more comfortable.

mobility.title: Gently Massage Your Dog's Legs
mobility.text: Massaging can improve circulation and reduce discomfort, making it easier for your dog to move.

mobility.title: Engage in Low-Impact Play with Gentle Toys
mobility.text: Toys that encourage gentle play can help keep your dog active without risking injury or discomfort.

mobility.title: Consult a Vet for Specific Physical Therapy Exercises
mobility.text: A professional can recommend exercises tailored to your dog's needs, promoting mobility and strength without causing harm.

mobility.title: Create a Safe, Accessible Environment
mobility.text: Ensure your home is dog-friendly, with ramps or steps if necessary, to help your dog move around easily without having to jump or climb.

mobility.title: Monitor Weight to Reduce Joint Stress
mobility.text: Keeping your dog at a healthy weight can significantly reduce the strain on their joints and make movement easier.

mobility.title: Consider Mobility Aids
mobility.text: For dogs with significant mobility issues, aids like harnesses or wheelchairs can offer support, making it possible for them to enjoy more freedom and activity.

encouragement.title: Capture Special Moments
encouragement.text: Take photos of your dog to preserve the memory of your shared joy. A picture can freeze a moment of happiness for a lifetime.

encouragement.title: Celebrate with New Toys
encouragement.text: Introduce new games or toys on good days, adding excitement and variety to your dog's playtime.

encouragement.title: Enjoy Extra-Long Cuddle Sessions
encouragement.text: Make the most of good days with extended cuddle time, strengthening your bond and providing comfort.

encouragement.title: Create a Paw Painting
encouragement.text: Engage in a fun art project by creating a paw painting with your dog, making for a unique and lasting keepsake.

encouragement.title: Document Happy Days in a Journal
encouragement.text: Write about your dog’s good days in a journal, detailing the joy and memorable moments you share.

encouragement.title: Organize a Mini Photo Shoot
encouragement.text: Dress your dog in fun outfits and set up a photo shoot at home, capturing their personality and your creativity.

encouragement.title: Explore New Trails or Parks
encouragement.text: Discover new outdoor spaces with your dog, enriching their environment and stimulating their senses.

encouragement.title: Set Up a Dog Playdate
encouragement.text: Arrange for your dog to meet and play with friends, encouraging socialization and shared enjoyment.

encouragement.title: End the Day with a Storytime Session
encouragement.text: Read to your dog, allowing your voice to soothe and relax them, creating a peaceful end to a good day.

encouragement.title: Start a Happy Moments Box
encouragement.text: Collect mementos of your dog's good days, such as toys, photos, or small notes, in a special box you can revisit together.

encouragement.title: Prepare a Special Meal
encouragement.text: Cook a dog-safe meal or treat to celebrate a particularly good day, showing love through their favorite flavors.

encouragement.title: Visit a Dog-Friendly Café or Store
encouragement.text: Share a new experience with your dog by visiting a place where they are welcome to join in the fun.

encouragement.title: Have a Relaxing Spa Day
encouragement.text: Pamper your dog with a gentle bath, followed by a grooming session to make them feel loved and refreshed.

assessments.hurtInfo: Is {{petName}} painfree? Or can {{petName}}’s pain be successfully managed?

hurtOptions.title: Severe Pain
hurtOptions.description: {{petName}} shows clear signs of pain, like whimpering or difficulty moving, and can't seem to get comfortable.

hurtOptions.title: Moderate Pain
hurtOptions.description: Shows some discomfort, especially when moving or breathing, might avoid being touched in certain areas.

hurtOptions.title: Mild Pain
hurtOptions.description: {{petName}} seems slightly uncomfortable at times but can still rest and move without too much trouble.

hurtOptions.title: Occasional Discomfort
hurtOptions.description: Rare signs of discomfort, mostly able to move and rest without issues.

hurtOptions.title: Pain-Free
hurtOptions.description: {{petName}} is comfortable, moves easily, and shows no signs of pain.

hungerOptions.title: Refuses to Eat
hungerOptions.description: {{petName}} won't eat anything, even their favorite treats.

hungerOptions.title: Struggles to Eat
hungerOptions.description: Shows interest in food but has difficulty eating without assistance.

hungerOptions.title: Eats with Encouragement
hungerOptions.description: Eats only when encouraged or hand-fed, but not eagerly.

hungerOptions.title: Eats with Minor Issues
hungerOptions.description: Eats less than usual or prefers soft food, but generally manages on their own.

hydrationOptions.title: Refuses to Drink
hydrationOptions.description: Won't drink any water, showing possible dehydration signs like lethargy, dry gums, and a dry nose.

hydrationOptions.title: Needs Assistance to Drink
hydrationOptions.description: Shows interest in water but can only drink when helped.

hydrationOptions.title: Drinks a Little
hydrationOptions.description: Drinks on their own but less than usual, might need reminders.

hydrationOptions.title: Drinks with Encouragement
hydrationOptions.description: Drinks a sufficient amount, though might need some coaxing or prefer certain ways of drinking.

hydrationOptions.title: Hydrated and Healthy
hydrationOptions.description: Drinks regularly without any issues, maintaining good hydration.

assessments.hygieneInfo: Is {{petName}} clean and comfortable? Is {{petName}} able to stay clean?

hygieneOptions.title: Severely Unkempt
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} is often dirty, might have matted fur, and frequently soils themselves.

hygieneOptions.title: Needs Frequent Help
hygieneOptions.description: Can sometimes stay clean but often needs assistance to avoid lying in waste or staying clean.

hygieneOptions.title: Occasionally Messy
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} is mostly clean but may have occasional accidents or need help with grooming.

hygieneOptions.title: Generally Clean
hygieneOptions.description: Stays clean with minimal assistance, may just need help with difficult-to-reach spots.

hygieneOptions.title: Always Clean
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} manages their hygiene well, stays clean, and does not soil themselves.

assessments.happinessInfo: Does {{petName}} express joy and interest? Does {{petName}} respond to their surroundings (family, toys, etc)?

happinessOptions.title: Severely Depressed
happinessOptions.description: Shows no interest in interaction, toys, or activities that used to be enjoyable.

happinessOptions.title: Often Uninterested
happinessOptions.description: Occasionally shows a glimmer of their old self, but mostly disinterested in surroundings or activities.

happinessOptions.title: Mildly Interested
happinessOptions.description: Shows interest in interactions or toys but less than before, enjoys being with family but may tire easily.

happinessOptions.title: Generally Happy
happinessOptions.description: Engages with family and toys, shows signs of happiness, but not as frequently or enthusiastically as before.

happinessOptions.title: Fully Joyful
happinessOptions.description: {{petName}} is responsive, enjoys interaction, play, and being part of the family activities as always.

assessments.mobilityInfo: Can {{petName}} get up without assistance? Does {{petName}} feel like going for a walk?

mobilityOptions.title: Immobile
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} cannot move on their own at all. They need assistance for every movement and cannot stand up, walk, or change positions without help.

mobilityOptions.title: Severely Limited
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} can barely move and needs significant help to stand, walk, or reposition. They might only manage very short distances with support.

mobilityOptions.title: Moderately Limited
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} can move a bit on their own but needs assistance or encouragement for longer distances or getting up from a lying position.

mobilityOptions.title: Slightly Limited
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} is mostly mobile but shows signs of difficulty with some movements, like climbing stairs or jumping onto higher surfaces.

mobilityOptions.title: Fully Mobile
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} moves freely without any sign of discomfort. They can run, jump, and play as they always have, showing no hesitation or difficulty with any movement.
